# Part 1: Geopolitics of Continental and Maritime Powers

Continental and maritime empires ran business in fundamentally different ways—how they wanted to organize themselves and how they wanted to organize others. But then the Industrial Revolution came and put both of them out of business and introduced a maritime, incoming, rules-based order.

For those of you who like animals—and we at the Naval War College generally speaking, most of us like animals—the maritime powers are the whales; the elephants are the continental powers. The first distinguishing characteristic of maritime versus continental powers is whether you can or cannot defend primarily at sea. Look at Ukraine—they cannot defend primarily at sea. So, if you can, having a big Navy would be a thing for you, and if you can only defend by land, then you need to go to Army. These differences have profound military, economic, and political ramifications.

The United States started out as a traditional, typical continental power. Here’s President Monroe and the Monroe Doctrine—typical continental power, spheres of influence, telling the Europeans, “Stay out of the Americas, it’s ours.” And here’s how the United States expanded, again like a typical continental power: it did a series of regional wars with Mexico, the longest counterinsurgency in U.S. history was fought against the Native Americans. But the twist that Americans liked was checkbook diplomacy, you know, paying money to people—and that’s what the Louisiana Purchase and buying Alaska were all about. Americans had a name for this: Manifest Destiny. It was the obvious, manifest fate of America, the United States—we appropriated the name for the entire continent—to own at least North America.

This painting, which today goes by the politically correct name of “Westward Ho,” at the time of painting was called “Westward, the Course of Empire Takes Its Way.” It hangs in the Capitol, apparently in some part of the House of Representatives. Americans in the 19th century considered themselves an empire—proud of it. But the view changes in the late 19th century. Here, Alfred Thayer Mahan, who is by far the most famous person ever associated with this college—of enduring international influence—looked at the world and thought, “Well, actually, it’s not so much continental consolidation that is the origin of power and position in this world, but the wealth accruing from maritime trade.”

Mahan said there are six prerequisites for playing this game of maritime security paradigm. Number one: you need a moat, insulation from attack. Number two: you need a dense internal transportation grid to get the goods out in peacetime. Number three: you need reliable egress by sea to get the Navy out in wartime. Number four: you need a dense coastal population—these are the people running this commerce-driven economy. Number five: you need the commerce-driven economy that goes with them. Number six: you need stable government institutions—this is going to mean you have stable laws that promote commerce and also promote the Navy.

If you look at China and Russia today, neither one of them has a full list of six. Start with the moat—they most certainly do not have moats, either one of them. In fact, they each have more neighbors than any other two countries on the planet, and a lot of those places don’t much like them for excellent reasons. Moreover, China has an improving internal transportation grid, but Russia’s remains lamentable. Neither one has reliable access by sea because they’re all surrounded by narrow, island-cluttered coastal seas, surrounded by all kinds of neighbors that shut down in wartime. Russia’s got the big Arctic thing—well, great if you want to go court with polar bears, that’s a place for you, but not for commerce. In addition, China has a dense coastal population, Russia doesn’t. Russia has never had a commerce-driven economy, and under Deng Xiaoping, China was more so, but in recent years, Xi Jinping has been privileging the crony sector over the private sector. Neither China nor Russia has stable government institutions—regular, transparent transfers of executive power. Dictator for life does not remotely qualify.

China and Russia have some maritime ambitions, but they don’t have the geopolitical position actually to play the game, and I’m not even clear they understand it.

# Continental Empires: Historical Context and Expansion

If you look at China, it shows you a lot of vertical real estate there, and the flat stuff up north, a lot of it is either awfully cold or awfully dry to grow much of anything. If you look at where the Han live—the preponderant ethnic group of China—it’s all the pink places. You can see where they live, and they’re surrounded by heterogeneous ethnic groups. If it’s a simplified ethnic map, what you realize is that the Han occupy all the prime real estate. The curious might ask, “How did that happen?” The answer would be, they laid waste to the competing Xiongnu and Mongol empires. You haven’t heard about the Xiongnu—the Qing dynasty wiped them out hundreds of years ago. This is how continental empires run business: either you get with the program, or they will kill you. It’s a binary choice—either you become Han, honorary Han, or that’s it. In our own day, I believe the Uyghurs are slated for genocide. This is not a world for the faint-hearted.

For a sanitized version of Chinese history: the Hans started out up there in the Yellow River Valley and then they spread, and they spread, built some walls too, and spread, and did all this crazy stuff, coming and going. Then there’s a lot of consolidation before this happens to them—the Yuan dynasty. It looks like just a bigger version of what I’ve been showing you, except there’s a major discontinuity: these Yuan dynasty, they’re Mongols. But the Han reassert themselves under the Ming. The Mongols only last for a century, but then the Ming succumb to the second largest empire in Chinese history—the Qing. They aren’t Han either; they’re Manchu.

# The Maritime World and the Industrial Revolution

Here’s the maritime world—it’s different. I love this picture—it shows all of the commerce going on in the 19th century and shows the Atlantic as a very busy place, the center of the world economy. All of these sea lines of communication are connecting trade from all the coastlines, traversing the ocean, which is a commons, a shared space. Think about it in our own highly networked age—the seas are the world’s original network, potentially connecting everyone with everything.

This maritime world goes back to the ancient Greeks, who had a rimland empire along the Aegean and Ionian Seas, making a lot of money from trade. The Roman Empire had a similar idea—a rimland empire, very different from the consolidated empires of Russia and China. Look at the terminology: Mediterranean—middle of the lands, the sea among the lands. China’s name is Zhongguo—central kingdom, the kingdom among the kingdoms. One emphasizes the centrality of the sea, the other, the centrality of the land.

The Silk Road connected these two worlds, East and West, and there’s been much money to be made on East-West trade for a very long time. Whoever controlled the western terminus—the big toll booth—made a lot of money. The Muslim conquests settled that problem for a while; no one controlled the rims, and this is when the Crusades take place. The Ottomans controlled it for a long time, so the Spanish and Portuguese got creative and decided to get to Asia the long way around, except they bumped into the New World—new to them, not to others—and found gold and silver. The Dutch were the real people who focused on an empire that’s all about trade and trading bases. Their problem was their exposed position in Europe, so they could be defeated in Europe.

The real pioneers of maritime empire were the British. Every other country in Europe had to maintain a large, potentially coup-generating standing army, which is expensive and will want economic policies to privilege the army. Britain could take its dependence on trade and transform it into an advantage: if they could make lots of money on trade, that would fund a Navy, and if anyone tried to invade, they’d drown at sea. Meanwhile, while their adversaries were busy destroying wealth, Britain maximized its money. This is a prevent-defeat strategy: no one’s going to invade Britain if they keep a good Navy, but it doesn’t deliver victory against continental problems.

Britain coined the term “grand strategy”—grand in the multiplicity of instruments of national power that are integrated. Navies rarely deliver victory in war; usually, you need other things to go on as well. After much trial and error, the British had six coalitions, a final capstone alliance, and they dealt with Napoleon. Here is their grand strategy for elephant hunting, used to great effect in World War II: keep the home economy growing—that’s where your money is, that funds your military and allies. Don’t let the enemy elephant forage—shut them down and force them back on dwindling resources and increasingly embittered allies. Rent an elephant—find the continental power most directly threatened by your problem, arm and fund them. Find a theater peripheral to the main theater that favors maritime access, so you can have cumulative effects on the enemy, force them to fight with divided attention, and relieve pressure on the main front. If Britain chooses the right theater, casualties are far lower than in the continental problem. Rule five: don’t take on the elephant as your opening move; don’t go toe-to-toe with your continental problem, because Britain’s great strength is not its army. Only get involved on the main front after bleeding the elephant and coming in with lots of friends.

If Britain plays this game, it can put itself and its enemies on opposing trend lines—Britain gets wealthier and wealthier if it can trade, and war undermines the enemy’s territory, economy, morale, and productivity. Eventually, the story is, they get exhausted first. It’s a strategy of exhaustion, focusing not only on military power but economics, coalitions, institution-building. Prerequisites: sanctuary at home, access to markets, allies, peripheral theaters, and institutional stability at home for long-term foreign policy—some of what Mahan emphasized.

This brings me to the second distinguishing characteristic between maritime and continental powers: continental powers face contiguous threats, so they want to be insulated from neighbors and have exclusion zones—applied to the seas as well. Maritime powers, due to their comparative security, want access to international markets and the seas as a commons that everyone can share. So, focus on insulation versus access to markets; desire for closed versus open seas. We’re starting to get to two very different world orders here.

The Industrial Revolution upended both types of empires by introducing economic growth whose compounding effects were truly revolutionary. It started in Britain, moved to the continent, and has been making its disruptive path around the world ever since. It’s based on a combination of institutional and technological factors. The currency of international power changed: formerly, power was a function of land, for commodities and conscripts. Once you have compounding growth, the source of power is money from trade, industry, and commerce. The disruptive effect for traditional society was global; suddenly, their security paradigms didn’t work anymore. Who’s rich and who’s poor today is about degrees of industrialization.

# Third Distinguishing Characteristic: Lines of Communication and Alliances

The transportation revolution that makes it so much cheaper to ship things by sea leads me to my third distinguishing characteristic: continental powers did quite well with interior lines of communication to garrison their empire, deploy their armies, and form alliances with contiguous places. Maritime powers use exterior lines—oceans provide access to global markets, wartime allies, and the possibility of a global alliance system. The third characteristic is reliance on interior versus exterior lines of communication and the ability to have a contiguous or global alliance system.

The Industrial Revolution upended the world not just because of cheaper transportation, but because it offered the possibility of a new positive-sum world order. Instead of wrecking your neighbors (the continental paradigm: destabilizing, invading, and destroying, so what you get is a wasteland), the maritime order is positive-sum. The continental order is negative-sum—because the loser’s loss is less than the winner’s win, you’re capturing damaged goods. In the maritime order, it’s all about positive-sum trade transactions where both parties win. That’s why you do trade.

For this to work, the focus is on freedom of navigation, free trade, international laws, and institutions facilitating trade to minimize transaction costs. The insurance system for all of this is alliances. Countries that aren’t maritime by geography, if they join up with enough others, can operate on a maritime security paradigm. Here’s the insurance system for all of this, created by the greatest generation—the World War I generation, not the World War II who claimed it. The World War I generation were conscripts trying to raise families during the Great Depression, then became the strategic leaders of World War II and sent their kids to fight. They decided that the solution to war and depression was institution-building on a global scale—rapidly building the UN, IMF, NATO, predecessor institutions of the EU and World Trade Organization, to hold the peace institutionally. It worked in the industrialized world until Vlad the Bad overturned the chess table in Ukraine.

The maritime world is invisible. It took me 15 years working here for it to dawn on me what was going on. It has to do with the difference between negative and positive objectives. The continental world is about positive objectives: you’re taking land, and when you take or try to take it, you’re wrecking things, so people can see what’s going on. The maritime world, particularly if you’re successful, is about negative objectives—you’re preventing stuff from happening. Operationally, you can have all these wins in the continental world, but actually you’re destroying wealth at the strategic level. In the maritime world, you’re preventing things: for the Navy, the focus is mostly on negative objectives in peacetime (which, by the way, is most of the time). The Navy is preventing the destruction of the global trading system—that’s an important mission. Preventing limits on freedom of navigation—if you can’t get goods port to port, it’s useless. Navies are about deterring people from taking other people’s territory—sovereignty being the bedrock of international law.

On a good day, Navy day, absolutely nothing happens—looks like the Navy is doing nothing, but it’s incredibly important. Maritime powers hold it together with alliances, diplomacy, sanctions, embargos, containment. The Navy’s deterrence: blockades, commerce raiding. Sanctions and other measures may not seem to have immediate effect, but over a few generations, the difference between North and South Korea is significant. You’re shrinking the opposing piggy bank. Solving the whole problem isn’t always feasible—if the whole problem has nuclear weapons, the solution may be Armageddon. This world isn’t about operational wins—it’s about the strategic win of maximizing wealth for you and your allies.

# Recap: Continental vs Maritime Powers

There are three characteristics that distinguish continental and maritime powers: the (in)ability to defend primarily at sea; focus on insulation from versus access to the world; and reliance on interior versus exterior lines of communication. From these accidents of geography come some preferences: continental preference for territory, self-sufficiency, exclusion zones; maritime preference for markets, access, and commons—not only maritime, but air, cyber, and space commons. A lot of countries aren’t strictly one or the other, so there’s a continuum.

You can gain a maritime position by the countries and institutions you support, so that collectively the whole thing can operate on a maritime security paradigm. The choice is consequential: those who choose a continental paradigm these days typically are dictators who wind up hemorrhaging cash to dominate their own citizens or neighbors. China, by rejoining the maritime system under Deng Xiaoping, transformed from a very poor country to a far richer country. But older continental predilections still exist—they seem to be taking a U-turn on this road. The continental world is negative-sum; the only positive-sum order humans have come up with is this maritime order. For all its flaws, at least there are institutions where you can go, send your lawyers and diplomats, and argue things out. The alternative is potentially terminal for mankind if you get into a big war.

# Part 2: The Last Cold War – Causes, Consequences, and Explanations

Let’s move to the Cold War—there was one, and it turned out quite well. Is there anything we can glean from this? How did it turn out the way it did? Some people take comfort in saying Ronald Reagan won the Cold War. That’s one way of looking at it, but there are many explanations.

What Ronald Reagan did was a big military buildup, and the Russians, at the end of the Cold War, had as much as 70% of their economy devoted to the military—it was absolutely suffocating. The Nazis in hot war spent only 55% of their economy on it, so it was a problem for the Soviets. I’ll be quoting a lot of Russians today, because they thought deeply about what happened to their country.

Here’s Valentin Falin, long-time Soviet ambassador to Germany. He said, look, the American strategy of our exhaustion in the arms race just wrecked our quality of life. Russia had not only problems with the United States but also with China, so the arms race plunged the Soviet economy into a permanent crisis.

Here’s Georgy Arbatov, the Soviet premier expert on the United States, watching Reagan funding anti-communist counter-insurgencies all over the world—destroying wealth by having both sides funding insurgencies. In Afghanistan, he said, “Yeah, we got our Vietnam.” So some would argue that U.S. victory in the arms race determined victory in the Cold War.

Let’s go through other presidents, because there are other arguments, starting with Ford, Carter, and the Helsinki Accords. After World War II, the Soviets wanted a European-wide conference for everyone to agree on their expanded borders. For the longest time, Europeans weren’t interested, but by the ’70s, they were sick of the drama. The U.S. wasn’t interested, but we showed up and insisted on human rights clauses—which we knew they wouldn’t respect. The third basket of the Helsinki Accords was human rights. Lo and behold, human rights activists in the West and dissidents throughout the Warsaw Pact started trying to hold the Soviet government accountable: “Where is the liberation that communism promised? Why are we dealing with this dictatorship that’s been delivered?” And by the way, you signed all these things. This dissident movement, the human rights movement, took on a life of its own.

Jimmy Carter then ran with it, giving a commencement address at Notre Dame: “We have reaffirmed America’s commitment to human rights as a fundamental tenet of our foreign policy. What draws us together is a belief in human freedom. We want the world to know that our nation stands for more than just financial prosperity—we’re bigger than that.” Carter was emphasizing precisely the political freedoms being denied throughout the Eastern bloc.

Here’s Anatoly Gromyko, long-time Soviet diplomat: Communist ideology was associated above all with the Soviet Union, and when you reject it, a vacuum, a real problem, results. Some would argue that the human rights clauses of the Helsinki Accords and Carter’s campaign destroyed belief in communism, and that’s why it all ended.

Others say, “Nonsense—it’s Richard Nixon and the China card.” Or it’s Mao and the America card. In 1969, Russia and China were going at it in a border war over some islands in the Amur River. The Russians approached the United States: “Would it be okay if we nuke these people?” The U.S. said, “No way.” Mao figured it out: the one that wants to nuke you is the primary adversary. Prior to this, the U.S. had been China’s primary adversary; after, China and Russia are each other’s primary adversaries, and the U.S. becomes the swing vote, ganging up with China against Russia. This forced Russia into a bankrupting militarization of its long frontier with China—it had already militarized its European frontier, now it had to put mechanized, nuclear-armed forces there. Imagine if the U.S. had to do this on both Canadian and Mexican borders—it would be bankrupting.

So, U.S. cooperation with China fatally overextended the Soviet Union. You could also say each president opened opportunities for successors: Nixon plays the China card, Ford keeps using it, and starts playing the human rights card, Carter runs with that, begins a military buildup that Reagan really runs with. Reagan and Bush later operate from a position of military and ideological strength. For those who think U.S. foreign policy wasn’t consistent during the Cold War, you’re wrong: the policy objective was relentless—free trade, democracy, containment of communism. Republicans and Democrats agreed on that; they had different strategies, but agreed on the goal.

Others would say, forget the great man theory of history—it’s this platform, the nuclear-powered submarine, that determined the outcome. Under Carter and Reagan, there was a much more aggressive strategy of targeting Soviet nuclear subs in their home bastions, and the Soviets were scared to death that they didn’t have reliable second-strike capability. Here’s Marshal Akhromeyev, in the U.S., telling his host, “We’re surrounded, that’s why we’re concerned. We know that you know where our subs are, and we don’t know where yours are. You, the United States Navy—they, the problem. Go Navy.” The USSR could not counter, technologically or financially, the U.S. submarine threat and to its retaliatory nuclear forces. Some would argue that’s why they had to settle the Cold War.

# The Soviet Side: Collapse and Self-Destruction

All the preceding explanations are “navel explanations” (with an “e”), all about what Team America did or didn’t do. Let’s get to the other side: what was Team Russia up to? Arnold Toynbee, one of the finest historians of the 20th century, observed that civilizations die from suicide, not by murder. I’ve been talking about the murder—what others did to the Soviet Union—now I’ll get to the suicide, the self-defeating things the Soviets did.

Explanation number one: they lost the empire, the Cold War, because their empire collapsed—the domino theory supposed to apply to capitalism actually applied to communism. Once the democratic contagion hit one Warsaw Pact country and demonstrations for freedom started, they spread to others. The leaders of these countries no longer had the stomach for the violence it would take to get demonstrators off the street. Gorbachev’s ideas of “glasnost” (openness) and “perestroika” (rebuilding) resonated throughout Russia and Eastern Europe. Russians hit the streets demonstrating for political freedoms; in Eastern Europe, they demonstrated for freedom from the Soviet Union.

Gorbachev encouraged people to reform; he didn’t send tanks into the Eastern bloc. Instead, he told them to do political and economic reforms the way we are. These reforms started in Poland, which had a history of unrest. In 1988, Solidarity, the workers’ movement, gained national and international reputation—it was the only independent opposition movement of any Warsaw Pact country. The economy was a mess, the government needed to raise staple prices, Solidarity hit the streets, the government feared freefall, so they offered Solidarity a place at the bargaining table if they’d call off the strikes. A complicating factor in Poland is the Roman Catholic Church—an institution of enormous legitimacy, with a partiality for Solidarity.

Talks started in February 1989—the Round Table Talks. Here’s Soviet advice to the Poles: “You’ve got to find some quick solutions. You’re an itty-bitty country, so if you make mistakes, they’ll be itty-bitty mistakes; if we make them, they’ll be big.” The Communist Party in Poland decided to hold elections, on the very same day that Deng Xiaoping called out the tanks and the Tiananmen Massacre occurred—two very different solutions. The Communist Party thought they had it under control with party-designated seats, but Solidarity won every seat it could compete for, and in the party-designated seats, the party got only three—the rest went to “none of the above.” That was the end of Communist Party legitimacy in Poland. Further democratic reforms cascaded into East Germany. In the past, East Germany would have sent tanks, but “Tankman” Erich Honecker was already out of a job, his disastrous strategy of living off debt having wrecked the place.

Most of the Politburo resigned by November. They issued new travel rules. At a press conference, Gunter Schabowski was asked, “When are the travel regulations going to be implemented?” Not wanting to admit he didn’t know, he winged it: “Immediately.” Huge crowds started massing at the gates of East Berlin; at one, the border guards decided discretion was the better part of valor, opened it, and people streamed into West Berlin. Within a week, over half the country had visited West Berlin. Like the Polish elections, opening the gate meant there was no going back—the world had changed.

Here’s Anatoliy Kovalev’s take—longtime deputy foreign minister of the Soviet Union: there was no confidence whatsoever in whom the East German army would shoot—us or the demonstrators. Same thing for the Poles and Hungarians—great alliance system, right? Unrest in the empire forced the Union to forfeit the Cold War.

Another argument: the satellites themselves were terribly unhealthy, and that’s the origin of the problem. Circa 1960, all those tempting green places were about to become independent; enter the Soviet Union with a plan to put them out of business. There were many takers. By the 1980s, all the promising pink places where the Soviets had all kinds of new friends. But in the late ’70s, commodity prices (including oil) went way down. The Soviet Union’s budget depended heavily on oil—sometimes as much as 55%. Not only did the non-performing pals have no money and need bigger subsidies, but the Soviet Union was less able to subsidize them. Most problematically, Soviet internal nationalities erupted, all wanting to secede. Rule of continental empire: no two-front wars. The Soviets had so many fronts, they couldn’t keep track. By bankrupting itself in the Third World and ignoring its own internal Third World, the Soviet Union lost the Cold War.

Another argument: economics. The Soviet economy did well rebuilding after World War II but stagnated in the 1970s. In the decade before Gorbachev, the Soviet economy had been growing 1–2% less per annum compared to the West; the compounding effects are huge. In a command economy, Moscow central tells everyone what to produce, but units on the bottom lie about inventory and inputs, macroeconomic statistics are garbage, and capital and labor are misallocated. No one knows consumer preferences or productivity; misallocation is horrendous and no one figures it out until it’s catastrophic. Under Gorbachev, oil prices tanked, growth went negative, and economic growth goes negative. Marshall Akhromeyev looked at all this and concluded, “NATO—they’re just rich, we can’t counter these people; we’ve got to find a way to call it off.” The Soviet economy lost the Cold War.

Here is Alexis de Tocqueville and his famous chestnut: “The most dangerous moment for bad government is when it begins to reform.” People in Russia disagree about many things but agree that Gorbachev’s role was absolutely central in how it all turned out. Gorbachev made decisions based on incorrect assumptions: that history was irreversible, always forward toward communism, but Eastern Europe made a U-turn back to capitalism. He misread the sentiments of neighbors—thought Eastern Europeans would look upon him as their liberator, rather than as an interloper. He believed that bringing freedom to satellites would lead them to adopt “socialism with a human face.” He made an enormous mistake; these countries turned their back on Russia. The United States intervenes in civil wars all over the world but deluges them with economic aid and even leaves—people don’t like us, but we don’t stick around. Russians wonder why they’re so special.

Gorbachev also believed if there were no Warsaw Pact, there would be no NATO; no Comecon, no European Community. Wrong—two of those things are still around. He thought the United States, like a continental power, would oppose German unification. So Gorbachev goes on vacation while all the unrest is happening—poor life choice, because President Bush and Chancellor Kohl of Germany are coordinating on the fastest reunification of Germany ever. Some would argue that Gorbachev’s sins of commission caused the problems, that his foreign policy mistakes were a function of domestic policy mistakes, and together they killed the Soviet Union.

Others would argue it’s not about sins of commission, but sins of omission—what the Army failed to do. The Red Army should have done the Deng Xiaoping solution: send in the tanks. Timely tank deployment—TTD—would have changed the outcome.

Still others say it’s not sins of omission but commission by Boris Yeltsin, Gorbachev’s successor—he got rid of Article Six in the Soviet Constitution, which had given the Communist Party the monopoly of power; now you have multi-party competition. He signed the Belavezha Accords that dissolved the Soviet Union—so, suicide on purpose.

# Summing Up the Collapse

You can give umbrella explanations: maybe any of the above reasons, or all of

them. There were so many problems with the Soviet Union, you could argue its demise was inevitable—it was brutally inefficient. The West didn’t like it because of this; it wasn’t that any U.S. president did anything—the Russians figured it out, invented it, and wanted to get rid of it. The Soviet Union was destined to lose—that’s an optimistic way of looking at it.

A pessimistic way: the Cold War ended very much on Western terms because it required all of these factors—the whole list I gave you today. Remove any one of them and you get a different outcome—maybe you don’t even end the Cold War. It took the whole shebang, so the West barely won the Cold War. Another twist: not only did it take everything, but you needed Bush and Kohl in office at the same time. Bush had a long résumé, and Kohl was the longest-serving chancellor of West Germany since Bismarck. They worked on fast-tracking unification by letting East Germans travel, paying big money to let more people out, and then doing tag-team diplomacy—offering big money to Gorbachev that he couldn’t refuse, as the Soviet economy imploded.

A month and a half before reunification, Saddam Hussein invaded Iraq—a major Soviet client state. Bush finessed this, not going too far into Iraq to upset the Soviets, and also finessed Margaret Thatcher and François Mitterrand—neither wanted to see a unified Germany, since it would eclipse their own countries. Mitterrand negotiated the Maastricht Treaty to create the European Union, bringing in all Eastern European countries and merging with the European Community. Thatcher just plain lost—she wanted Soviet troops in Germany for the duration. Imagine dealing with Putin today if she’d had her way.

# Conclusion and Possible Ways Forward

That’s it for the underlying geopolitics and what was done last time around. Now, what do we do?

In the first half, I talked about elephant hunting—how the British ran their strategy, which worked in World War II. But there’s a huge difference now: it’s precision nuclear strike—none of us has an invulnerable home anymore. By all means, keep the economy running and probably your friends’ economies running; by all means, close down enemy trade—not with blockades and commerce raiding, but much better with sanctions. Sanctions: “I’m going to buy stuff or I’m not, sell stuff or I’m not.” Then, on peripheral theaters, help people who are beset by continental problems, but you must be cautious.

The goal of maintaining prosperity hasn’t changed. Last time around, the West, Japan, and South Korea all parried the nuclear threat—not through nuclear bombs, but through economic growth. As the maritime world compounded economic growth, the communists were living in compounded poverty. Don’t despair: people in the West during the Cold War—most people—were living quite well, much better than the communists. There was prosperity while all this was going on.

The current Cold War will go on for generations, because you don’t change how other people think—they decide. Changing what they thought—Gorbachev and his generation, Deng Xiaoping and his—took time. It’ll take the Russians and Chinese a long time to change.

From the Cold War section, you can extract U.S. strategy: extensive military buildup with allies, a broad strategic communications campaign (not just human rights at the end, but from the beginning—accurate news to subject populations: Radio Free Europe, Voice of America, etc.), lots of alliance-building for friends and alliance-busting for enemies. Amplify overextension of your enemy—all the stupid things they’re doing. The Soviet Union was overextended—occupying someone else’s country and staying forever is not efficient. The Russians were abusive, we leveraged that, and they had a non-performing economic model. Amplify those errors.

Geography, without us lifting a finger, naturally contains Russia and China—they’re surrounded by narrow seas, just facts. Those narrow seas in peacetime don’t matter, but in hot war, merchant traffic doesn’t go and your navy won’t either if you’re located on a really narrow sea. Putin and Xi, and whoever else is bothering you, don’t have a coherent alliance system. It’s a bunch of Eurasian dictators—they share the U.S. as a secondary enemy, but their primary enemies are different. Russia’s primary enemy is Ukraine, China’s might be Taiwan, India, or someone else; Iran’s is Israel, Pakistan’s is India, North Korea’s is South Korea. None of this aligns for meaningful sacrifices for each other. Compare that to World War II alliances—there was agreement on Germany as the primary theater, primary enemy. The Axis had different theaters and enemies, dispersing their resources.

Today, Vladimir Putin is trying to reconstitute an empire in the age of nationalism. Good luck—dominated peoples no longer sit supine and take it, they resist. The Belt and Road initiative: Putin is dumping his arsenal into Ukraine, leaving Siberia open to Chinese ambitions. China is peeling away from the Russian sphere of influence in Central Asia—that Belt and Road thing is quite threatening for Putin, not so much for us.

In the last Cold War, the Russians kept it cold—proxy wars, other people did the fighting. Now, Vladimir Putin is doing the fighting himself. Back then, Russia was strong, China was weak; now, the tables have turned. Siberia has resources China would like; the territories the Romanov dynasty took from China exceed U.S. territory east of the Mississippi. The Chinese haven’t forgotten. Putin says boundary treaties don’t matter; the Chinese can play that back at him. Siberia has water—North China has blown through its water table, Baikal has over 20% of the world’s surface freshwater, and the Chinese can pipe it down if they wish. The question isn’t if, but when the Sino-Russian relationship will break up.

The problem with misidentifying your primary adversary and fighting a recreational war: Nicholas II thought Japan was his primary enemy, fought the Russo-Japanese War instead of preparing for Germany, and the dynasty was destroyed ten years later. Putin is emptying out his arsenal on Ukraine—the Ukrainians never wanted Russian territory; the Chinese might. If we play our cards right, the Russians and Chinese will take care of each other, but we’re going to be on a long wait while this occurs. It is better to have more friends in this world, and the maritime order, as flawed as it is, is your best bet—work with allies and friends through international institutions to coordinate against these “crazy people.”

That summarizes what I had to say today. Thank you for taking time late in the day to listen to me talk, talk, talk. I’ll be happy to answer any questions you all might have.
